Award.AwardTitle: Hydrogen oxidation reaction at alkaline polymer electrochemical interfaces: Achieving mechanistic understanding through surface sensitive spectroscopy
Award.AbstractNarration:
Professors Bingjun Xu and Yushan Yan of the University of Delaware are supported by the Chemical Catalysis program of the Division of Chemistry to develop a basic understanding of the electrochemistry of fuel cells and electrolyzers. Increased efficiency and reduced cost are key to the economical performance of these clean energy producing devices. Replacing the traditional precious metal containing components of these devices with less expensive metals reduces costs but results in lower efficiency. In this project a fundamental understanding of the interaction between the device components is developed to enable the use of inexpensive metals while maintaining or even improving their efficiency. Both K-12 and undergraduate students are involved in the project. In addition, a mobile device-based software application is developed to raise awareness on carbon footprint and the environment and provide a platform for sharing green energy related information.

The overarching goal of this research program is to understand the interaction of alkaline polymer electrolytes (organic cations) with electrodes at the molecular level, and its impact on the activity of the hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR). In-situ attenuated total reflection - surface enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy (ATR-SEIRAS) is primarily employed to correlate the molecular structure of free and tethered organic cations and their potential-dependent configurations when adsorbed on electrode surfaces. The chemistry of free and adsorbed organic cations, including their interactions with HOR intermediates and their impact on HOR activity and mechanism, are also investigated. The structure-activity relations established from this project guides the design of both hydroxide exchange membranes and electrocatalysts for electrochemical energy conversion devices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of this project are to elucidate the impact of species in the electrical double layer on electrode surface mediated reactions. This understanding is key to the development of efficient fuel cells and electrolyzers, which could substantially contribute to the generation and utilization of renewable electricity. During the funded period, we investigated several model reactions, i.e., hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR), and electrochemical reduction of CO2 (ECRCO2) and other organic compounds. On the intellectual merit front, we developed a spectroscopic technique capable of probing metal surface mediated electrocatalytic reactions at reaction conditions, i.e., operando attenuated total reflection-surface enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy (ATR-SEIRAS). We demonstrated that the interfacial pH substantially deviates upward from the bulk electrolyte in ECRCO2 with ATR-SEIRAS and proposed a quantitative method to determine the degree of deviation. The increased interfacial alkalinity contributed to the observed reactivity trend of ECRCO2 on Au and Ag. Through a combination of electrokinetic and spectroscopic investigations, we elucidated reaction mechanism of ECRCO2 and determined the rate limiting step on Au and Ag. In addition, we investigated the electrochemical reduction and coupling reactions of benzaldehyde and furfural on four metal surfaces, i.e., Au, Cu, Pt, and Pd, with drastically different product distribution. The reduction of benzaldehyde to benzyl alcohol occurs selectively, while the hydrogen evolution reaction dominates on Pt and Pd. Cu not only catalyzes the formation of benzyl alcohol, but also mediates the C-C coupling reaction to hydrobenzoin. Results obtained in this project provide novel and molecular level insights into several important reactions occurring at the electrochemical interface, which guide the design and development of next generation electrocatalysts and devices for renewable energy applications. During the course of the project, two graduate students were trained and we conducted outreach activities in a minority-focused high school.
